normalised: so, what exactly *is* organic farming? it means steering clear of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides. instead, farmers like ram singh ji in rajasthan rely on things like cow dung (gomutra and all!), compost made from vegetable waste, and natural pest control methods like introducing ladybugs to munch on aphids. it's also about crop rotation, planting different crops in the same field at different times to keep the soil healthy and prevent pests from building up.

unnormalised: So, what exactly *is* organic farming? It means steering clear of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides. Instead, farmers like Ram Singh ji in Rajasthan rely on things like cow dung (gomutra and all!), compost made from vegetable waste, and natural pest control methods like introducing ladybugs to munch on aphids. It's also about crop rotation, planting different crops in the same field at different times to keep the soil healthy and prevent pests from building up.
normalised: why bother with all this effort? well, for starters, organic food is generally considered to be healthier. no nasty chemicals lingering on your veggies! plus, organic farming is kinder to the environment. it helps to improve soil health, reduce water pollution, and support biodiversity. think about it – more bees, more butterflies, and a healthier ecosystem overall. even the air gets a little cleaner.

normalised: of course, organic farming isn’t always a walk in the park. yields can sometimes be lower than with conventional methods, especially in the beginning. it takes time and patience to build up healthy soil. farmers also need to be extra vigilant about pests and diseases. institutions like the I A R I are doing a lot of research to help organic farmers overcome these challenges, developing improved organic farming techniques.

unnormalised: The initial investment in setting up an organic farm can be higher, involving things like composting pits and natural pest control measures, potentially costing Rs. 50,000 or more depending on the land area, perhaps a 1000 sq ft plot initially. But in the long run, the benefits outweigh the costs. And with government schemes and NGOs promoting organic farming, getting started is becoming easier. Dr. Sharma, an expert from Punjab Agricultural University, often gives lectures on effective organic farming practices. So, next time you're at the market, look for the organic label. Supporting organic farmers is supporting a healthier future for everyone. Jai Kisan! It's a matter of going back to the basics, and taking care of Mother Earth.
